content:
Imagine you are a robot browsing the web, just like humans. Now you need to complete a task. In each iteration, you will receive an Observation that includes a screenshot of a webpage and some texts. This screenshot will feature Numerical Labels placed in the TOP LEFT corner of each Web Element.
Carefully analyze the visual information to identify the Numerical Label corresponding to the Web Element that requires interaction, then follow the guidelines and choose one of the following actions:
1. Click a Web Element.
2. Delete existing content in a textbox and then type content. 
3. Scroll up or down. Multiple scrolls are allowed to browse the webpage. Pay attention!! The default scroll is the whole window. If the scroll widget is located in a certain area of the webpage, then you have to specify a Web Element in that area. I would hover the mouse there and then scroll.
4. Wait. Typically used to wait for unfinished webpage processes, with a duration of 5 seconds.
5. Go back, returning to the previous webpage.
6. Google, directly jump to the Google search page. When you can't find information in some websites, try starting over with Google.
7. Answer. This action should only be chosen when all questions in the task have been solved.

Correspondingly, Action should STRICTLY follow the format:
- Click [Numerical_Label]
- Type [Numerical_Label]; [Content]
- Scroll [Numerical_Label or WINDOW]; [up or down]
- Wait
- GoBack
- Google
- ANSWER; [content]

Key Guidelines You MUST follow:
* Action guidelines *
1) To input text, NO need to click textbox first, directly type content. After typing, the system automatically hits `ENTER` key. Sometimes you should click the search button to apply search filters. Try to use simple language when searching.  
2) You must Distinguish between textbox and search button, don't type content into the button! If no textbox is found, you may need to click the search button first before the textbox is displayed. 
3) Execute only one action per iteration. 
4) STRICTLY Avoid repeating the same action if the webpage remains unchanged. You may have selected the wrong web element or numerical label. Continuous use of the Wait is also NOT allowed.
5) When a complex Task involves multiple questions or steps, select "ANSWER" only at the very end, after addressing all of these questions (steps). Flexibly combine your own abilities with the information in the web page. Double check the formatting requirements in the task when ANSWER. 
* Web Browsing Guidelines *
1) Don't interact with useless web elements like Login, Sign-in, donation that appear in Webpages. Pay attention to Key Web Elements like search textbox and menu.
2) Vsit video websites like YouTube is allowed BUT you can't play videos. Clicking to download PDF is allowed and will be analyzed by the Assistant API.
3) Focus on the numerical labels in the TOP LEFT corner of each rectangle (element). Ensure you don't mix them up with other numbers (e.g. Calendar) on the page.
4) Focus on the date in task, you must look for results that match the date. It may be necessary to find the correct year, month and day at calendar.
5) Pay attention to the filter and sort functions on the page, which, combined with scroll, can help you solve conditions like 'highest', 'cheapest', 'lowest', 'earliest', etc. Try your best to find the answer that best fits the task.

Your reply should strictly follow the format:
Thought: {Your brief thoughts (briefly summarize the info that will help ANSWER)}
Action: {One Action format you choose}
Confidence: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating your confidence level in the action. A higher value means greater confidence.}
Completion: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating how much of the task has been completed until now. Zero means no progress has been made and one means full completion.}

Then the User will provide:
Observation: {A labeled screenshot Given by User}

Now given a task: Find the GitHub Skill section and how many courses are under the 'First day on GitHub' heading.  Please interact with https://github.com/ and get the answer.Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: To find the "GitHub Skill" section and details about the 'First day on GitHub' heading, I need to locate the relevant resources or learning materials on GitHub. The "Resources" menu (label 6) is the most likely place to find courses or skills-related sections.
Action: Click [6]
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.2
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The "Learning Pathways" option (label 12) under the "Resources" menu sounds most relevant for finding the "GitHub Skill" section and courses like 'First day on GitHub'. Navigating there is the next logical step.
Action: Click [12]
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.3
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I have reached the "GitHub Learning Pathways" page, which should contain various learning resources including GitHub Skills. However, a cookie consent banner is blocking part of the screen. To better view and interact with the content, I should accept the cookies.
Action: Click [11]
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.4
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I am on the "GitHub Learning Pathways" page, but I do not see the "GitHub Skill" section or any course listings yet. I need to scroll down to find more detailed content and locate the relevant sections.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; down
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.45
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The visible pathways are "AI-powered development with GitHub Copilot," "CI/CD with GitHub Actions," "Shift left with GitHub Advanced Security," and "Administration and Governance with GitHub Enterprise." There is no sign of the "GitHub Skill" section or "First day on GitHub" heading yet. I should continue scrolling to locate these sections.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; down
Confidence: 0.97
Completion: 0.5
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I still do not see the "GitHub Skill" section or the 'First day on GitHub' heading. The current section displays learning pathways for specific features. I should scroll down further to locate the required section for GitHub Skills.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; down
Confidence: 0.97
Completion: 0.55
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The current section features testimonials from industry professionals and does not relate to "GitHub Skill" or "First day on GitHub." I need to continue scrolling down to find the section with courses or GitHub Skills.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; down
Confidence: 0.97
Completion: 0.6
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The current section continues to show testimonials and logos of various companies, not the "GitHub Skill" or any course section. More scrolling is required to find the relevant heading and related courses.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; down
Confidence: 0.97
Completion: 0.65
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Now I see the "GitHub Learning Pathways" heading which introduces self-paced tutorials. This section is likely to contain the "GitHub Skill" and potentially the 'First day on GitHub' heading or pathway. I should continue scrolling further to locate those specific sub-sections and the number of courses.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; down
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.7
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The page introduces learning pathways and best practices, but the specific sections for "GitHub Skill" and 'First day on GitHub' heading with course counts are still not visible. I need to scroll down further to find the detailed course listings or navigation to GitHub Skills.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; down
Confidence: 0.97
Completion: 0.75
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I’ve reached the bottom of the pathway section, and the main content is not listing a "GitHub Skill" section or courses for 'First day on GitHub.' The "Start your learning pathway" button may lead to a more detailed or interactive set of course options.
Action: Click [8]
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.8
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The section shows four primary learning pathways but does not present the "GitHub Skill" section or the 'First day on GitHub' heading. Since I haven't seen an option for GitHub Skills directly in this area, trying the "Learn" dropdown in the navigation bar (label 4) may provide access to GitHub Skills or introductory courses like 'First day on GitHub.'
Action: Click [4]
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.85
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The dropdown under "Learn" is open, presenting options like "GitHub Learning Pathways," "Documentation," and "GitHub Certifications." To locate the GitHub Skill section and possibly find the 'First day on GitHub' heading (as these may be covered under skills/courses), the next best step is to look for any further navigation inside the "GitHub Learning Pathways" option.
Action: Click [7]
Confidence: 0.97
Completion: 0.9
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: This is the top of the "GitHub Learning Pathways" page. To find the detailed course sections, including potentially "GitHub Skill" and 'First day on GitHub', I need to scroll down to see more of the page content.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; down
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.92
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: This section displays four main learning pathways, but none match "GitHub Skill" or directly reference 'First day on GitHub.' The required information is likely further down the page, possibly among more basic or introductory course offerings.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; down
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.94
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: At the bottom of the main pathway section, there are options to "Explore your learning pathway" for different focus areas, but still no sign of the "GitHub Skill" section or the 'First day on GitHub' heading. Since the next section is "Featuring expert insights from," the basic or introductory skills section is likely further down the page.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; down
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.96
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: This section contains user testimonials and not the GitHub Skills or course listings required. To find the "GitHub Skill" section and the 'First day on GitHub' courses, I need to continue scrolling further down the page.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; down
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.97
